DOC.HEAD: Albania Denies Yugoslav Newspaper Report Of Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Albania on Tuesday condemned as a ``fabrication'' a report in a Yugoslav newspaper about an alleged demonstation in the Albanian city of Shkodra. The Belgrade daily Politika Ekspres on Tuesday quoted sources in the southern province of Kosovo bordering Albania, as saying there had been a demonstration in Shkodra, a town 50 miles north of the capital Tirana near the Yugoslav border. The report said the protests took place in the last few days, but added there was no reliable report on the reasons for the alleged demonstrations. The Albanian state news agency ATA on Tuesday refuted the report as ``invented, tendentious and ill-willing.'' It said ``no kind of demonstration has been staged in the city of Shkodra.'' The Albanian ambassador to Vienna, Engyell Kolaneci, also condemned the report as a ``fabrication'' which he said was ``untrue.'' Relations between non-aligned Communist Yugoslavia and hard-line Communist Albania have long been strained over the ethnic Albanian population of Kosovo province. Albania alleges they are discriminated against, but leaders in the republic of Serbia, of which Kosovo is an adminstrative part, charge Albania with interference in its internal affairs.
